chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the value of the firm, both levered and unlevered, using the given parameters.

The firm value, as the name already suggests, is a measure of how much a business is worth. There are two measures that we can use for this: levered and unlevered. 

Levered firm value is the total of the market value of the equity and the debt. Unlevered firm value uses a debt-free model which means that the value of the firm only reflects the market value of its equity.

We can then substitute the given values in the problem to get the unlevered firm value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Unlevered firm value}&=\dfrac{\$31,200 \times(1-0.22)}{0.11}\\[15 pt]
&=\$221,236.36
\end{aligned}$$

The current value of the firm is $\$221,236.36$

**b.)** For this question, we will now look at the levered firm value since it assumes two scenarios of debt where the firs is a debt equal to $50\%$ of the unlevered value and the second being $100\%$ of the unlevered value. 

The levered firm value can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Levered firm value}&=\text{Unlevered firm value}\\
&+(\text{Value of debt} \times \text{Tax rate})
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see from the formula we need to solve for the value of debt. The value of debt refers to how much of the total value of the company is debt. In the first scenario, it states that the debt is $50\%$ of the unlevered firm value. This will then give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of debt}&=\$221,236.26 \times 0.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$110,618.13
\end{aligned}$$

The value of debt for the first scenario is $\$110,618.13$

Solving for the levered firm value of the first scenario, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26\\
&+(\$110,618.13 \times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$245,572.25
\end{aligned}$$

The levered value of the firm for the first scenario is $\$245, 572.25$

For the second scenario, we will use the unlevered firm value as the value of debt. Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26\\
&+(\$221,236.26 \times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$269,908.24
\end{aligned}$$

The levered firm value of the second scenario is $\$269,908.24$

**c.)** In this problem, we will use the same concept and formulae as in part **b.** but this time, we will use the levered value for the basis of the debt. 

For the first scenario, the levered firm value will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26\\
&+[(\text{Levered firm value} \times 0.50) \times 0.22]\\[15 pt]
\text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26+0.11\times \text{Levered firm value}
\end{aligned}$$

To simplify this, we will isolate the unknown on one side.

$$\begin{aligned}
0.89\times \text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26\\[15 pt]
\text{Levered firm value}&=\dfrac{\$221,236.26}{0.89}\\[15 pt]
&=\$248,580.07
\end{aligned}$$

The levered value of the firm is $\$248,580.07$

We can then simplify this by isolating the unknown on one side.

$$\begin{aligned}
0.78\times \text{Levered firm value}&=\$221,236.26\\[15 pt]
\text{Levered firm value}&=\dfrac{\$221,236.26}{0.78}\\[15 pt]
&=\$283,636.23
\end{aligned}$$

The levered firm value for this scenario is $\$283,636.23$

To recall the concepts in this problem, we must take note that the value of a firm can be solved using the levered and unlevered value.

The main difference between the two is that the levered value takes the debt in consideration while the unlevered value uses a debt-free model. 

As we can see from the results, the levered vlaue of the firm is higher than the unlevered.
